metadata.description: Sample categorizations for reference and LLM training

inputPaper.title: Neural Link Prediction for Drug Repurposing via Heterogeneous Biomedical Networks
inputPaper.abstract: We propose a novel graph neural network architecture for predicting drug-disease associations in heterogeneous biological networks. Our method learns entity embeddings from HetioNet, a large-scale knowledge graph integrating genes, diseases, drugs, and pathways. We evaluate using 5-fold cross-validation and achieve AUC-ROC of 0.89, outperforming baseline methods including random walks (0.82) and matrix factorization (0.85). We also report precision and recall metrics. Retrospective validation recovers 78% of known drug repurposings discovered after 2010.

categorization.reasoning: Paper proposes a novel GNN architecture (algorithmic novelty) for link prediction in biomedical networks. Clear method contribution with comprehensive evaluation. Abstract provides all required information including dataset (HetioNet), metrics (AUC-ROC, precision, recall), and validation approach (retrospective).

inputPaper.title: Transitive Inference with Semantic Filtering for Biomedical Hypothesis Generation
inputPaper.abstract: This paper introduces a method for literature-based discovery using transitive A-B-C inference with novel semantic filtering constraints. We extract concept co-occurrences from PubMed abstracts and apply semantic compatibility checks using biomedical ontologies (UMLS, GO) to filter spurious connections. Evaluation on historical drug repurposing cases shows our method achieves precision@100 of 0.43 compared to 0.21 for baseline co-occurrence methods. We use temporal split evaluation, training on pre-2000 literature and testing on 2000-2010 discoveries. The method is evaluated retrospectively on known discoveries including fish oil for Raynaud's disease.

categorization.reasoning: Novel method extending traditional ABC transitive inference with semantic filtering constraints. Algorithmic contribution is the semantic compatibility checking mechanism. Uses text-based co-occurrence with ontologies for filtering.
categorization.notes: Classic LBD approach with clear algorithmic novelty in filtering mechanism. Temporal split is ideal for LBD evaluation.

inputPaper.title: Materials Property Prediction via Knowledge Graph Embeddings and Link Prediction
inputPaper.abstract: We develop a materials science knowledge graph from 240,000 abstracts and apply TransE embeddings with deep learning for predicting material properties. Our system predicts thermoelectric properties, achieving Hits@10 of 0.67 and MRR of 0.45. We use random 80/20 train-test split and evaluate on held-out material-property associations. We also report Hits@5 and Hits@20 metrics. Case studies demonstrate discovery of novel thermoelectric candidates, with two materials subsequently validated in lab experiments.

categorization.reasoning: New method applying knowledge graph embeddings to materials science. Uses custom-built KG from literature abstracts. Clear algorithmic approach (TransE + deep learning) with both computational metrics and lab validation.
categorization.notes: Good example of prospective validation - two materials validated in lab. Materials science domain is growing area for LBD.

inputPaper.title: GPT-4 Assisted Hypothesis Generation for Materials Discovery
inputPaper.abstract: We present a framework for automated scientific hypothesis generation using GPT-4. Our system prompts GPT-4 with material science abstracts and generates novel hypotheses about material properties. We evaluate generated hypotheses through expert review by 12 materials scientists, who rate novelty and plausibility. Results show 23% of GPT-4 hypotheses are rated as both novel and plausible, compared to 15% for baseline methods. We demonstrate the approach on battery materials and catalysts.

categorization.reasoning: Paper proposes using GPT-4 as the core mechanism for hypothesis generation. This is clearly LLM-based discovery, which belongs to the 'LLM ideation' taxonomy rather than traditional LBD. Method is novel in its application but should be filtered from this corpus.
categorization.notes: Paper should be excluded from LBD corpus and moved to LLM ideation taxonomy. Uses language model as primary discovery mechanism rather than knowledge graphs or symbolic methods.

inputPaper.title: Large Language Models for Drug Repurposing: A Prompt-Based Approach
inputPaper.abstract: We fine-tune BERT on PubMed abstracts and use it to generate drug repurposing candidates through masked language modeling. Our approach predicts missing entities in drug-disease-gene triples extracted from literature. We achieve F1-score of 0.71 on a held-out test set of known associations, outperforming word2vec embeddings (0.63) and co-occurrence baselines (0.55). We use 5-fold cross-validation for evaluation.

categorization.reasoning: Uses fine-tuned BERT with masked language modeling as the core discovery mechanism. LLM-based approach that should be filtered. Although it uses structured triples, the discovery happens through language model predictions.
categorization.notes: Borderline case - uses structured triples but discovery mechanism is LLM-based (BERT masked prediction). Should filter to LLM ideation category.

inputPaper.title: A Comprehensive Survey of Literature-Based Discovery Methods in Biomedicine
inputPaper.abstract: This survey systematically reviews 87 computational methods for literature-based discovery in biomedicine published between 1986 and 2021. We categorize methods by data representation (knowledge graphs, text-based, ontologies) and discovery mechanism (transitive inference, link prediction, semantic similarity). We compare evaluation practices across methods, finding that 62% use retrospective validation while only 18% report prospective experimental validation. We identify key challenges including knowledge graph incompleteness, evaluation biases, and lack of standardized benchmarks. Finally, we discuss future directions including neural methods and LLM integration.

categorization.reasoning: Comprehensive systematic review of 87 methods with structured categorization and comparison. No new method proposed; the contribution is the survey itself. Includes taxonomy, evaluation practice analysis, and future directions typical of survey papers.

inputPaper.title: Towards Semantic Integration in Literature-Based Discovery: A Conceptual Framework
inputPaper.abstract: We argue that current literature-based discovery systems lack sufficient semantic integration, relying primarily on statistical co-occurrence rather than deep semantic understanding. We propose a conceptual framework emphasizing the role of ontologies, semantic relations, and contextual knowledge in discovery. Our framework extends Swanson's ABC model by incorporating semantic compatibility constraints between concepts. We discuss how this framework could address current limitations including high false positive rates and lack of mechanistic explanations. We outline a research agenda for developing semantically-aware discovery systems.

categorization.reasoning: Paper argues for a conceptual approach ('we argue that') and proposes a conceptual framework without implementation. Extends existing model theoretically. Focus is on ideas and positions rather than implementation or comprehensive review.
categorization.notes: Conceptual extension of Swanson's model. 'Research agenda' and 'could address' indicate no implementation provided.

inputPaper.title: Evaluation Biases in Literature-Based Discovery: A Critical Analysis
inputPaper.abstract: We critically examine evaluation practices in literature-based discovery research, identifying several methodological issues. First, retrospective validation often uses knowledge that was already implicit in training data, leading to inflated performance metrics. Second, most studies lack prospective validation, making it unclear if methods generate genuinely novel discoveries. Third, temporal data leakage is common when papers use publication dates rather than when knowledge entered the database. We analyze 45 LBD papers and find that only 12% avoid these issues. We propose guidelines for more rigorous evaluation including proper temporal splits and prospective validation requirements.

categorization.reasoning: Critical analysis of evaluation practices in LBD research, identifying methodological issues and biases. Focus is on limitations and problems rather than proposing new methods or comprehensive survey. Proposes guidelines but doesn't implement solutions.
categorization.notes: Clear methodological critique focusing on evaluation biases. Analyzes existing methods rather than surveying them comprehensively.

inputPaper.title: A Tutorial on Using Semantic MEDLINE for Biomedical Hypothesis Discovery
inputPaper.abstract: This tutorial provides a step-by-step guide for researchers to use Semantic MEDLINE for literature-based discovery. We explain how to formulate queries, interpret semantic predications, and filter results. We demonstrate the workflow through three case studies: discovering drug repurposing candidates for rare diseases, identifying gene-disease associations, and finding novel drug-drug interactions. We provide code examples, command-line instructions, and best practices for result validation. The tutorial is designed for biomedical researchers with basic computational skills.
inputPaper.venue: BMC Medical Informatics and Decision Making

categorization.reasoning: Educational paper providing step-by-step instructions for using existing tool (Semantic MEDLINE). Includes code examples, command-line instructions, and case studies for pedagogical purposes. Target audience is practitioners learning to use the system.
categorization.notes: Clear tutorial format with instructional focus. No method contribution - teaches use of existing system.

inputPaper.title: BioDiscovery: A Web Platform for Literature-Based Hypothesis Generation
inputPaper.abstract: We present BioDiscovery, an integrated web platform for biomedical hypothesis generation. The system combines PubMed search, named entity recognition using MetaMap, and existing link prediction algorithms from prior work. Users can query diseases or genes and receive ranked lists of potential discoveries. The platform integrates DrugBank, UniProt, and KEGG databases. We demonstrate the system through case studies on Alzheimer's disease and diabetes. The platform is freely available at biodiscovery.example.com.

categorization.reasoning: Paper describes a web platform integrating existing tools (MetaMap, existing link prediction) rather than proposing new algorithms. Focus is on system integration and usability. No algorithmic novelty mentioned in abstract.
categorization.notes: Uses 'existing link prediction algorithms from prior work' - key phrase indicating no novel method. System integration contribution.

inputPaper.title: Discovering Novel Targets for Alzheimer's Disease Using Semantic MEDLINE
inputPaper.abstract: We applied Semantic MEDLINE to discover novel therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease. Using semantic predications extracted from PubMed, we identified 23 candidate genes with potential neuroprotective effects. We filtered candidates based on biological plausibility and existing evidence. Follow-up literature review confirmed that 8 of these genes were subsequently investigated in Alzheimer's research within 5 years. This case study demonstrates the practical utility of literature-based discovery tools in neurodegenerative disease research.

categorization.reasoning: Applies existing tool (Semantic MEDLINE) to specific domain (Alzheimer's disease) without methodological contribution. Focus is on domain-specific findings and demonstrating utility of existing approach. Results are about domain discoveries, not method performance.
categorization.notes: Clear application paper. Uses existing system and reports domain-specific results rather than method development.

inputPaper.title: Undiscovered Public Knowledge
inputPaper.abstract: This paper introduces the concept of literature-based discovery through two case studies. First, we demonstrate how migraine-related research and research on magnesium effects, when considered together, suggest that magnesium deficiency may be related to migraine. Second, we show how fish oil and Raynaud's disease research, though disjoint, suggest a therapeutic connection. We propose the ABC model where A (disease) and C (treatment) are linked through B (intermediate mechanism) found in separate literatures. We use MEDLINE co-occurrence analysis and manual literature review to identify these connections. This approach reveals implicit knowledge hidden in the growing scientific literature.

categorization.reasoning: Swanson's foundational paper introducing the field of literature-based discovery. Proposes the ABC model that became the basis for the field. Historical importance and field-defining contribution don't fit modern method/survey categories. Belongs in 'Other' as foundational work.
categorization.notes: Seminal foundational paper. Introduced LBD as a field and the ABC model. Historical significance and conceptual foundation rather than a modern method or survey.

notes: These samples cover all major paper types and illustrate key categorization decisions. They can be used for LLM training, validation, or as reference examples when categorizing ambiguous papers.
